title: Bartering second-tithe produce
vignette: In Jerusalem Levi says to Judah: “Here is tithe wine; give me oil in exchange.”

options.text: Barter is fine – equal-value swap benefits both.
Forbidden; tithe produce may only be given as a free gift.

title: Betrothing with cattle-tithe proceeds
vignette: A man tries to betroth a woman with an unblemished tithe-calf.

options.text: Valid – the calf has monetary worth.
Invalid; sacred property may not be used for marriage.

title: Who owns the hide?
vignette: Tithe-coins buy an animal for food; after slaughter the hide is worth more than the meat.

options.text: Hide is secular; owner keeps the profit.
Hide is holy; its value must also be eaten in Jerusalem.

title: Illicit purchases with tithe money
vignette: Mistakenly buying water or salt with tithe-coins.

options.text: Deal stands; use the goods in Jerusalem anyway.
Deal void; restore the coins’ sanctity and dispose of the goods.

title: Buying slaves or land with tithe-coins
vignette: Shimon purchases a field using second-tithe money.

options.text: Transaction valid – treat land as investment for future meals.
Prohibited; must earmark an equivalent sum for food in Jerusalem.

title: Anointing with tithe oil
vignette: May a pilgrim use second-tithe olive oil as body lotion in Jerusalem?

options.text: Yes; oil counts as ‘eat, drink, or anoint’.
No; tithe must be eaten, not smeared.

title: Paying the porter
vignette: Owner asks a friend to carry tithe produce to Jerusalem. May he reward him with a share of that produce?

options.text: Yes; fair compensation for labour.
No; giving a share turns tithe into barter.

title: Swapping with a non-observant vendor
vignette: A pilgrim with tithe-coins wants to buy produce from an ignoramus (*am ha-aretz*).

options.text: Permitted – treat coins like cash; buyer just eats in purity.
Forbidden – risk of ritual impurity undermines sanctity.

title: Taking tithe produce out of Jerusalem
vignette: Left-over figs already inside the city – may the pilgrim haul them back home?

options.text: Allowed; intent to return suffices.
Disallowed; once inside, produce is ‘locked in’.

title: Produce that only passed through the city
vignette: Crates of finished grain entered Jerusalem in transit and left. Does their tithe now have to be eaten there?

options.text: Yes; Beth Shammai – entry alone creates the obligation.
No; Beth Hillel – owner may redeem and eat anywhere.

title: Unclean tithe inside vs. outside
vignette: Second-tithe fruit becomes impure. Where must the redemption money be consumed?

options.text: Redeem and eat within Jerusalem (except severe outside impurity).
Redeem and eat outside (except light impurity inside).

title: Does the wine-jar become holy?
vignette: Merchant sells sealed jars of tithe-wine. Do the empty jars acquire sanctity?

options.text: Yes; vessel value joins the wine.
No; only the contents are holy.

title: Father redeems a minor’s tithe
vignette: A father redeems his young son’s second-tithe produce. Must he add the standard one-fifth surcharge?

options.text: Yes; treat the child’s tithe like one’s own (Rabbi Yehuda).
No; surcharge applies only when redeeming your own produce (Tanna Kamma).

title: Coin-for-coin redemption to avoid the surcharge
vignette: A pilgrim exchanges small-denomination tithe coins for one large coin, mainly to dodge the extra one-fifth payment.

options.text: Permitted; any redemption that lightens the load is valid (The Sages).
Forbidden if the aim is to evade the surcharge (Rabbi Meir).
